generalPrinciples.name: Proportion & Scale
generalPrinciples.description: The relationship between the artwork, mat, and frame dimensions
guidelines: Matting should generally be proportional to the artwork size
Larger artwork typically requires wider matting
Small artwork benefits from wider matting to increase presence
Standard mat width ratio is 1:3:2 (top/sides:bottom for weighted mats)
Frame molding should be proportional to artwork and mat size
commonErrors: Matting too narrow for the artwork, creating a cramped appearance
Frame molding too heavy for delicate artwork
Frame molding too thin for substantial artwork

generalPrinciples.name: Color Harmony
generalPrinciples.description: The coordinated use of colors across artwork, mat, and frame
guidelines: Mats should complement, not compete with, the artwork
Extract mat colors from secondary or tertiary elements in the artwork
Neutral mats (white, off-white, black) work with most artwork
Frame finishes should harmonize with the overall color scheme
Consider the wall color where the framed piece will hang
commonErrors: Choosing a mat color that matches the dominant color in the artwork
Using colors that clash with the artwork's palette
Selecting frame finishes that conflict with the artwork's tone
Creating too many competing colors in one framing design

generalPrinciples.name: Conservation Standards
generalPrinciples.description: Preservation techniques to protect artwork from damage
guidelines: Use acid-free, lignin-free materials for all valuable artwork
UV-protective glazing for light-sensitive pieces
Proper mounting techniques that avoid permanent adhesives
Spacers to prevent artwork from touching glazing
Sealed backing to protect from dust and pollutants
commonErrors: Using non-archival materials for valuable artwork
Direct contact between artwork and glazing
Improper mounting techniques that damage artwork

generalPrinciples.name: Visual Balance
generalPrinciples.description: Creating equilibrium in the framed presentation
guidelines: Consider visual weight of frame elements
Create intentional symmetry or asymmetry
Use weighted bottom mats for traditional presentations
Ensure frame style complements the artwork's composition
Mat width should balance artwork and frame
commonErrors: Frame style that competes with the artwork's composition

recommended: Ornate gold frames for traditional/classical subjects
Simple wood frames for landscapes and casual subjects
Linen liners instead of mats for traditional presentations
framingGuidelines.matting: Often displayed without mats, or with linen liners
framingGuidelines.glazing: Usually framed without glass to avoid moisture issues
framingGuidelines.mounting: Stretched canvas can be secured directly in frame
framingGuidelines.conservation: Avoid direct contact between canvas and frame with frame bumpers

recommended: Delicate, light frames that complement the medium's subtlety
Traditional gold or silver frames for formal subjects
Simple wood frames for casual or naturalistic subjects
Conservation framing due to sensitivity to light and humidity
framingGuidelines.matting: Double or triple matting with white or off-white top mat
framingGuidelines.mounting: Archival hinging with Japanese paper and wheat starch paste
framingGuidelines.conservation: Full conservation package recommended due to sensitivity
